item.title: Week 4
item.description:
ğŸ“… Week 4 (June 10â€“16): the second exam

The mathematical analysis exam took place on Tuesday. It included 4 theoretical questions and 3 problems â€” covering derivatives, extreme points, and definite integrals.
The problems were challenging, but I managed to recall all the required steps. Final result: 82 points.

ğŸ“Š Academic highlights:

  • Learned integration techniques: by parts and substitution.
  • Reviewed convergence criteria for numerical series.
  • Started wrapping up the semester â€” took notes on what to focus on during summer.

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
ğŸ“… Week 3 (June 3â€“9): first exam week

The programming exam took place this week. It included both a written and a practical section. In the practical part, we wrote Python functions and debugged code.
I scored 90 points â€” happy that all the preparation paid off. My debugging and testing practice really helped!

ğŸ“Œ Focus of the week:

  • Rewrote older assignments to get a deeper grasp of algorithms.
  • Started revising theorems and techniques for analysis â€” the second exam is coming soon.
  • Joined a group session to review math analysis problems â€” turned out to be very productive!

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
ğŸ“… Week 2 (May 27 â€“ June 2): peak of preparation

This week was all about mathematical analysis. In lectures, we covered limits, derivatives, and important theorems â€” Bolzano-Cauchy, Lagrange, and Rolle.
During practice sessions, we worked on proving convergence and analyzing functions. Challenging, but very engaging!

ğŸ“˜ Achievements:

  • Completed all programming lab assignments â€” wrote parsers and basic sorting algorithms.
  • Passed the logic credit test successfully.
  • Made condensed notes for the math analysis exam â€” super handy for revision!

item.title: Week 1
item.description:
ğŸ“… Week 1 (May 20â€“26): the start of exam season

This week we completed the final module in mathematical logic. There was a fascinating lecture on propositional calculus and the concept of deductive systems.
In the seminar, we practiced problems on proving the derivability of formulas â€” not everything worked on the first try, but it became clear how important it is to structure logical reasoning clearly.

ğŸ” Highlights of the week:

  • Final logic test â€” scored 85 points!
  • Read a chapter on normal forms and reviewed CNF and DNF.
  • Started preparing for the programming exam: revised Python topics â€” lists, dictionaries, and functions.
